question.title: DeepSeekChatModel could not be found
question.body:
We try to build a DeepSeek client app with Spring AI. We follow the Spring AI getting started to set up the dependencies. And following the Spring AI DeepSeek Chat document, we had a controller as described in the guide as:


@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/deepseek")
public class DeepSeekController {

    private final DeepSeekChatModel chatModel;


    public DeepSeekController(DeepSeekChatModel chatModel) {
        this.chatModel = chatModel;
    }

    @GetMapping("/ai/generate")
    public Map generate(@RequestParam(value = "message", defaultValue = "Tell me a joke") String message) {
        return Map.of("generation", chatModel.call(message));
    }
}

But, we get a compilation error:

Parameter 0 of constructor in com.example.deepseekapi.DeepSeekController required a bean of type 'org.springframework.ai.deepseek.DeepSeekChatModel' that could not be found.

while the document says:

This will create a DeepSeekChatModel implementation that you can inject into your class. Here is an example of a simple @Controller class that uses the chat model for text generation.

We have the DeepSeek configuration in the configuration file shown in the document.

What is missing?

We had a look at the DeepSeekChatModel API documentation and can't see how to create its bean in the app. It requests at least the following parameters:

DeepSeekApi deepSeekApi, 
DeepSeekChatOptions defaultOptions, 
ToolCallingManager toolCallingManager, org.springframework.retry.support.RetryTemplate retryTemplate, 
io.micrometer.observation.ObservationRegistry observationRegistry

question_comments.body: I'm simply pointing out the docs linked suggest otherwise

What the compilation error says is that the Spring container can't find the bean, but not an un-injected bean. The requirement for the Autowired or Inject annotations for constructor injection was effectively removed in Spring Framework 4.3. The current release is 6.2.9.
You're missing @Autowired annotation, so where would the parameter otherwise come from?
